awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of A Single Crystal Diffractometer With A Silver Microsource and A Detector Optimized for Silver Radiation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Instrumentation Programs. Professor Mercouri Kanatzidis from Northwestern University and colleagues Kenneth Poeppelmeier, Sossina Haile, Steven Jacobsen and Danna Freedman are acquiring a single crystal X-ray diffractometer equipped with a silver micro-source, goniometer, and an efficient detector optimized for silver-radiation.  In general, an X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles, and provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. The studies described here impact many areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate and graduate students in chemistry and biochemistry at this institution where students receive hands-on access to the diffractometers and collect data on their own experimental samples. The new diffractometer is also used for the biannual international Summer School co-organized with the American Crystallographic Association and Northwestern University. Collaborations are in place with other research institutions such as the University of Chicago, the Ohio State University, Illinois Institute of Technology, Loyola University Chicago, Lake Forest College and Roosevelt University.  

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It is especially used for exploring solid state chemistry of chalcogenides and analyzing solid-state-related electrochemical processes. The diffractometer is also utilized for the analyses of synthesized compounds and minerals as well as synthesized oxides and oxide-fluorides. The instrument is employed in projects with applications in sustainable energy, geology, planetary sciences, ceramics and nanomaterials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Acquisition of A Single Crystal Diffractometer With A Silver Microsource and A Detector Optimized for Silver Radiation: This new, high energy X-Ray capability will enable investigators to obtain a deeper understanding of matter at the atomic scale, with applications in sustainable energy, geology, planetary sciences, and nanomaterials. Currently most of these projects can only be conducted utilizing synchrotron radiation.

The nation’s national security relies on the ability to develop novel materials needed to create a sustainable energy economy and reduce the reliance on foreign countries who provide starting materials, such as rare earth metals. These are fundamental materials questions that require characterization tools that are not limited to ambient conditions. The ability to monitor materials in harsh conditions will enable us to develop solutions to these pressing needs and teach the next generation of scientists to develop tools needed to conduct in-situ/operando measurements. This proposed instrument will be used to build on classes already taught at the graduate (Chem 432) and undergraduate (Chem 350) levels where students receive hands-on access to the diffractometers and collect data on their own experimental samples. Furthermore, the new diffractometer will be used at the international Summer School co-organized with the American Crystallographic Association that Northwestern hosts every two years. In total, Northwestern participates in training ~ 100 people per year attending tier one research institutions (e.g., University of Chicago, The Ohio State University, Illinois Institute of Technology), small colleges (e.g., Loyola, Lake Forest, Roosevelt) and businesses to collect data and refine structures through these activities. Finally, researchers will have the opportunity to optimize experimental setups based on experimental needs or before transferring experiments to a synchrotron which will make much more efficient use of this valuable resource.

In 2021, instrument was used for 1721 hours, by 14 different users from 5 research groups. All users were trained to operate the instrument on their own. So far, results from these data collections have been published in 5 peer-review papers, and data are reported in at least 6 submitted manuscripts. Additionally, optimization of hardware and software for total scattering measurements, which is not a turnkey application, was done in 2021. As a result of this optimization, one of the two published papers contain total scattering data on liquids which is not trivial to perform using in-house instrumentation.

Modified by: Mercouri G Kanatzidis
